column2: title
column24: repository
column25: abstract
column37: subject_name

column1: This is the file name / sequencing number that is used to match the descriptive metadata to the physical file.
column2: Title of object. Transcribe as found, construct a descriptive title if no title exists. Use with title_initial_article if applicable.
column3: Put any relevant initial articles for the title_of_work into this column. The rest of the title of the work, sans initial article, should appear in the title_of_work column.
column4: Enter any applicable rights information. See data dicitionary for more information.
column5: This is for name(s) of rights holder(s) of the resource. Format personal names in the following format: Last name, First name. Format corporate names in direct order, e.g., France-America Society. Use the name form found in the LCNAF when available, including birth and death dates or other information when present. Use VIAF or Getty ULAN if a LCNAF record does not exist.
column6: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the name.
column7: Put either conference, corporate, family or personal for the type of name.
column8: Use Still Image for nonmoving visual information, e.g., jpeg image. For film and video use Moving Image. For audio use Sound.
column9: The is the structured/key form of the date which can be used for searching. Follow EDTF formatting for single dates and ranges.http://bit.ly/2hhq8HP
column10: This is the display/human-readable form of the date. Date may be entered in structured form, e.g., 1935-07-09 or textual form, e.g., July 9th, 1935. Use circa, approximately, or other appropriate term, when the date is uncertain, e.g., circa 1945. Repeat if transcription/translated/transliteration needed.
column11: Indicate the type of date using one of the following values â€“ exact, approximate, inferred, or questionable.
column12: Select the appropriate term(s) to describe the physical form of the item from the Getty AAT.
column13: Enter the name of the relevant archival collection if applicable using the name that appears in the Archival Collections discovery layer (Scout). Do not use abbreviations.
column14: Include the identifier for the physical collection that the item to be digitized is a part of.
column15: Enter the unique numeric identifier in the 001 MARC field for items that have records in the catalog, format as 5504426.
column16: This is for names of creators/contributors of the resource. If someone is the subject of that resource, put them in subject_name. If someone is a publisher, use publisher instead. Format personal names in the following format: Last name, First name. Format corporate names in direct order, e.g., France-America Society. Use the name form found in the LCNAF when available, including birth and death dates or other information when present. Use VIAF or Getty ULAN if a LCNAF record does not exist.
column17: Enter the role of the person/organization named using the MARC relator and role codes - http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators.html
column18: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the name.
column19: Put either conference, corporate, family or personal for the type of name.
column22: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the name.
column23: Put either conference, corporate, family or personal for the type of name.
column24: Enter the name of the holding institution.
column25: Enter any relevant descriptive information. Please ensure that the descriptive information pertains to the digitized object specifically and not a larger work/collection/exhibition, as the context for the record will change over time.
column26: Enter a publication date if applicable.
column27: Enter information about the physical extent of an item (e.g., 1 score (ix, 12 pages) ) including dimensions. Specify the unit of measurement. [From UTK Data Dictionary: Provide the measurements in the form of height x width for two dimensional objects.]
column28: Select the appropriate term(s) from the LC Genre/Form Terms to describe the particular style or content of the object, such as artistic/musical genre, literary composition, etc.
column29: Use for the language of the item being cataloged/described. Use a MARC code form of the language - http://www.loc.gov/marc/languages/language_code.html
column30: Use the digital project/exhibit title here, as taken from the homepage.
column31: Enter any relevant information that should be publicly viewable but that does not belong in any of the other fields.
column32: Autogenerated to be University of Tennessee Libraries and Special Collections. Enter information only if this differs.
column33: Use for geographic subjects. Term should be taken from a controlled vocabulary such as Library of Congress Subject Headings or Name Authority File for political entities.
column34: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the geographic subject heading.
column37: Use for names/title subjects. Term should be taken from either the Library of Congress Name Authority File or FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology
column38: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the name subject heading.
column41: Use for topical subjects. Term should be taken from a controlled vocabulary such as Library of Congress Subject Headings. [For photographs, also use LC Thesaurus for Graphic Materials (LCTGM)]
column42: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the topical subject heading.
column44: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the topical subject heading.
column46: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the topical subject heading.
column48: Put the name or code for the authority from which you took the topical subject heading.
